elements.title: Cannonball (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the Cannonball (pictured), a commuter train on the Long Island Rail Road, was once operated exclusively with parlor cars?

elements.title: Piper Kelly (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Piper Kelly secured her position as a competitor in speed climbing at the 2024 Olympics by reaching the final race at the 2023 Pan American Games, before winning the race?

elements.title: a Bangladeshi government agency (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that a Bangladeshi government agency collected ৳6.5 billion (equivalent to US$150 million in 2023) from corruption suspects, but a court ruled it was illegal?

elements.title: Jamal Valizadeh (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that after Jamal Valizadeh was tortured in Iran, hid for six months, and escaped, he qualified to compete in the Olympics as a member of the Refugee Olympic Team?

elements.title: Union for Democracy and Social Progress (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the electoral victory of the Union for Democracy and Social Progress in 2018 led to DR Congo's first peaceful transition of power since its independence from Belgium in 1960?

elements.title: Spence Galbraith (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that in May 1983 British public health physician Spence Galbraith suggested withdrawing blood products made from blood donated in the U.S. after 1978?

elements.title: his sixth studio album (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Jack White released his sixth studio album unannounced by including unmarked vinyl copies of it with purchases made at Third Man Records stores?

elements.title: Aniya Holder (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Aniya Holder secured a spot at the 2024 Summer Olympics by winning a speed climbing competition, for which she had started training without even knowing that it was an Olympics qualifier?

elements.title: Erdős–Moser equation (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the only known solution to the Erdős–Moser equation is 1 + 2 = 3?
